courseDescription:
Are you interested in building a sound understanding of the fundamentals of financial management? This course will instruct you in every step to ensure that the concepts become crystal clear. We begin with a definition of the term ‘financial management’ itself and everything that it encompasses. We discuss the role of business managers in today's world and explore budgeting, a critical component, along with a step-by-step breakdown of the budgeting process.

Despite all advancements in financial management, even the best investors start by checking the company's financial statements. You will learn about financial statements using samples and an explanation of the breakdown of key components. The core of financial management lies in the analysis of trends and projections. You will identify the essential tools and ratios used in the professional world to determine the meaning behind the numbers presented in financial statements.

Are you constantly looking for ways to improve the performance of your department or company? One of the necessary aspects of performance management is benchmarking. We will examine the benchmarking process in detail. International businesses face even more challenges. You will identify the principal risks faced by organisations, both financial and otherwise, once they decide to go global. Financial management is a growing field. A thorough understanding of the basics can help you develop a lucrative career. So do not waste more time and enrol now to advance your learning journey.

  • Lesson Summary
  • Below you will find a summary of the key content covered during the module:
    • Financial management is described as the economics of time and risk. Modern financial management assumes that the primary objective of a business is to maximise shareholder wealth.
    • Some basic financial statements are - the balance sheet, profit or loss statement and the statement of cash flows.
    • A budget is a financial tool for estimating revenues and expenses for a specific period which is compiled and re-evaluated periodically.
    • There are four types of budgets: Incremental budgets, activity-based budgets, value proposition budgets and zero-based budgets.
    • A balance sheet represents snapshots of a company's financial position on the last day of each year. 
    • Assets that are expected to be converted into cash within a year are known as current assets, while liabilities to be settled within a year are current liabilities. 
    • The profit or loss statement, also known as the income statement, reflects the performance of the company during the given period.
    • The statement of cash flows shows how much cash the company is generating by separating a company's activities into three categories: Operating, investing and financing activities.

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Explain what a statement of changes in equity is along with its key components.
    • Identify some of the controversies that exist regarding the subject of stockholders' equity.
    • Discuss the process of interpreting and analysing financial statements through key ratios based on the target users.
    • Describe how all the financial statements are interrelated to one another when it comes to decision-making and trend analysis.
    • Compute the formula for the calculation of the Dupont equation and list its advantages.
    • Discuss the internationalisation of businesses along with its impact on risk and shareholder wealth.

  • Lesson Summary
  • Below you will find a summary of the key content covered during the module:
    • Changes in stockholders' equity during the period are reported in a financial statement called the statement of stockholders' equity.
    • Corporate governance is used to describe the ways in which companies are directed and controlled.
    • Financial ratios provide a quick and relatively simple means of assessing the financial health of an organisation.
    • Ratios can be grouped into categories relating to a particular aspect of performance or position - profitability, efficiency, liquidity, gearing, and investment.
    • Trend analysis analyses a firm's financial ratios over time and estimates the likelihood of improvement or deterioration over time.
    • The Dupont equation is a formula that shows that the rate of return on equity can be found by the product of net profit margin, total asset turnover and the equity multiplier.
    • Benchmarking is the process of comparing a company with a set of benchmark companies which are the best in class.
    • It can be possible to counter the risk of economic downturn in the home market by operating in the overseas market that are not exposed to the same risks.
